com:
Previous >>56304836
Guess no new cover edition.

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

com:
Hello. About a day ago I saw people talking about some "unusual" weapons they saw being used in Ukraine, in that case an F2000. He seemed to think that those weapons were somehow new, when in reality they're been present almost since the beginning of the war.

I don't fault him for thinking that but as a (semi) professional militaria dork I wanted to give you all a rundown on some of the weird and uncommon small arms I've seen in Ukraine, and where exactly they came from. Feel free to make a request if you'd like some specific information.

For our first example we have a PKT that was harvested from a knocked-out Russian tank and converted for infantry use. These got a decent amount of press coverage due to their unusual appearance, but I haven't seen them in use since about April or May. The facility where they were produced was eventually discovered and knocked out, and by now superior options are widely available.

There are a couple of reasons. It's a bit heavier than a lot of 74s. Neither the top rail, nor the handguard rails retain zero, and you can actually deform the handguard rails just by holding them. The stock doesn't fold flat to the side of the rifle, so slings and branches will catch it. The 2 round burst is stupid, and the selector switch is improperly made, so if you try to select something and use too much strength, you shove it off the gun and in front of the trigger guard.

The 2020 version may have solved some of these issues, but I'm not sure yet.

>>56369831
>Only upside I can see is Afro-Rome adopting firearms since they didn't have a culture of le warrior masculinity consider firearm a sissy weapon
Rome absolutely did have a culture of warrior masculinity. It's why it was always, ALWAYS at war. Social mobility relied on military exploits.
Roman formations, contrary to popular belief, were comparatively open and flexible to give individual soldiers a way to shine (in stark contrast to the Greeks), and Roman generals just plain duelling an opposing general is something that occasionally happened (also in contrast to the Greeks). Tellingly, the sources we have show that Roman soldiers tended to have discipline issues and openly protested when their generals were too timid - they wanted to murder more.
Of course, none of this would stop the Romans from adopting firearms en masse, because to the Romans, the greatest honour was to kill the enemy. The details didn't matter, and indeed, the Romans made specific exceptions to discipline for missile weapons (legionaries were allowed to leave formation to pick up and throw back a missile).

>Alpha Group
KGB/FSB's spetsnaz unit. As well as domestic/counter terror/police type stuff it runs operations abroad. Including black operations, assassinations. Remember FSB is essentially a political organisation loyal to Putin. So it's operations are often directly in support of Putin's political objectives in a way other intelligence organisations are not.

>Vympel
A tier 1 Ru SF unit. Originally responsible for missions outside Ru borders and ina military context, or security of overseas diplomatic missions. Think something like delta force. Like Alpha are part of the FSB. So more politicised than other spetz units.

>Spetsnaz
Special purpose troops. Often these are compared to western SF but that isn't accurate. They are more comparitive to RM commandos/rangers/FFL paras in quality. Spetsnaz is a generic term for anything that is more special than it ls home organisation. SWAT, Delta, seals, RM commandos, SAS, Smoke jumpers, specialist fireman etc are all spetsnaz to Russian eyes.

>Spetsnaz GRU
GRU or 'Main Directorate of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation' is the intelligent service of the Ru armed forces. Unlike many comparitive western organisations it performs both military focused tasks and runs intelligence officers in foreign countries. Imagine US army US Army Intelligence Corp and the CIA were the same organisation. GRU is responsible for all military spetsnaz operations. Think SOCOM or UKSF directorate.


In addition to all these Russia does have a foreign intelligence service (SVR) which Putin listens to less than his domestic ones. Prior to Feb they were apparently informing Putin of all the reasons an invasion of Ukraine was a bad idea, so Putin ignored them and listened to FSB telling him they would be welcomed as liberators instead.

Warlordism. Imagine all of these colonels and generals sitting out in bumfuck nowhere on huge military bases in the Far East. All of them want to feel special, this is why you have dozens of different bootleg camo patterns, gun-platforms, helmets, "spetsnaz" groups etc. This system of decentralized feudal lords that draw up masses of serfs in times of war is a holdover from the Middle Ages, a system that the West was able to dismantle but the mindset is very much alive in Russia. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56368345
Get a double-barrel percussion coach gun, 2-4 single-shot pistols, and a trench knife. And then remember you'll have to waterproof everything like a motherfucker and replace your charges every couple of months. This is fortunately pretty easy with a percussion gun, you can just drop some wax or varnish over the top of the cap once it's capped and use well-greased, tight-fitting wads. Flintlocks you have to prime immediately before use, or the priming powder will suck up water, go dead, and eventually corrode out your touch-hole and pan. Priming powder is incredibly sensitive to humidity. Your main charge will go bad more slowly but since you can't seal it it'll still eventually die.

>b-but muh revolvers
If you're retarded enough to think that using a BP weapon for home defense is a good idea you're too fucking stupid to operate a BP revolver without ruining it. If you really want the aesthetic buy a conversion cylinder for a blackpowder revolver.

>>56368169
The Mesoamerican bows likely were more primitive (that is, less dangerous) than atlatls.
http://elbdisliker.at.ua/Inuit/The_Bow_and_Arrow_in_Northern_North_Amer.pdf
Here's an article on the matter. To simplify, although bow and arrow were present in North America essentially from the beginning, they were shit, and repeatedly disappeared/were only in limited, regional use. This changed decisively around 700 A.D., when the 'Asian War Complex' (recurve bows, basically) reached the Aleutian islands, which led to a drastic reshaping of society (it became more warlike), and this technology then rapidly expanded southwards towards California and along the north of Canada before going south again.
The late woodland period is, of course, something that concerns eastern North America, but the appearance of bow and arrow no earlier than 700 A.D. has been noted as well:
https://www.nps.gov/fosm/learn/historyculture/woodlandperiod.htm
Given this late introduction further north, it is likely that more advanced bows had only just reached Mesoamerica by the time the Spaniards came knocking, or may even still have been missing altogether (somewhat less likely since the northern edges of Tiwantinsuyu did already have advanced bows, though).
